qas.question: What was the DBMS created by IBM called?
What was the purpose of the IBM DBMS?
What is the classification of IMS?
What was the name of Bachman's Turing Award presentation in 1973?
What was the DBMS designed for IBM by a third-party called?
What was irrelevant to the IBM DBMS?
What is the classification of IMS not considered?
What was the name of Bachman's Turing Award presentation in 1972?
When did IBM lose their own DBMS?

context: IBM also had their own DBMS in <b8_0>1966<b8_0/>, known as <a0_0><b4_0>Information Management System (IMS)<b4_0/><a0_0/>. IMS was a development of software written for <a1_0><b5_0>the Apollo program<b5_0/><a1_0/> on the System/360. IMS was generally similar in concept to CODASYL, but used a strict hierarchy for its model of data navigation instead of CODASYL's network model. Both concepts later became known as navigational databases due to the way data was accessed, and Bachman's 1973 Turing Award presentation was <a3_0><b7_0>The Programmer as Navigator<b7_0/><a3_0/>. IMS is classified[by whom?] as a <a2_0><b6_0>hierarchical database<b6_0/><a2_0/>. IDMS and Cincom Systems' TOTAL database are classified as network databases. IMS remains in use as of 2014[update].
